description: From Middle English direccioun, from Old French direccion, from Latin dīrēctiō. Equivalent to direct +‎ -ion.

entries.meaning: A theoretical line (physically or mentally) followed from a point of origin or towards a destination. May be relative (e.g. up, left, outbound, dorsal), geographical (e.g. north), rotational (e.g. clockwise), or with respect to an object or location (e.g. toward Boston).
examples: Keep going in the same direction.

entries.meaning: A general trend for future action.

examples: The trombonist looked to the bandleader for direction.

entries.meaning: The work of the director in cinema or theater; the skill of directing a film, play etc.
examples: The screenplay was good, but the direction was weak.

entries.meaning: (dated) The body of persons who guide or manage a matter; the directorate.

examples: Her aunt Leonella was still at Cordova, and she knew not her direction.
